message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Evolutionary dynamics of higher-order interactions in social networks
Paper Abstract: We live and cooperate in networks. However, links in networks only allow for pairwise interactions, thus making the framework suitable for dyadic games, but not for games that are played in larger groups. Here, we study the evolutionary dynamics of a public goods game in social systems with higher-order interactions. First, we show that the game on uniform hypergraphs corresponds to the replicator dynamics in the well-mixed limit, providing a formal theoretical foundation to study cooperation in networked groups. Second, we unveil how the presence of hubs and the coexistence of interactions in groups of different sizes affects the evolution of cooperation. Finally, we apply the proposed framework to extract the actual dependence of the synergy factor on the size of a group from real-world collaboration data in science and technology. Our work provides a way to implement informed actions to boost cooperation in social groups.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph"},{"title":"Line graph of a hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_graph_of_a_hypergraph"},{"title":"Balanced hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balanced_hypergraph"},{"title":"Bipartite hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartite_hypergraph"},{"title":"Packing in a hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packing_in_a_hypergraph"},{"title":"Hypergraph removal lemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph_removal_lemma"},{"title":"Discrepancy of hypergraphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrepancy_of_hypergraphs"},{"title":"Matching in hypergraphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matching_in_hypergraphs"},{"title":"Hypergraph regularity method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph_regularity_method"},{"title":"D-interval hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D-interval_hypergraph"}]

## Hypergraph Overview

A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.(no content)In contrast, in an ordinary graph, an edge connects exactly two vertices.

### Basic Definition and Structure

A hypergraph H is a pair (V, E), where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of subsets of V called hyperedges, where each hyperedge may contain one or more vertices.

### Key Concepts

**Uniformity**: A k-uniform hypergraph is one where every edge consists of exactly k vertices.

**Matching**: In graph theory, a matching in a hypergraph is a set of hyperedges in which every two hyperedges are disjoint, and it is an extension of the notion of matching in a graph.

### Applications

Undirected hypergraphs are useful in modelling such things as satisfiability problems, databases, machine learning, and Steiner tree problems.(no content)Applications include recommender systems (communities as hyperedges), image retrieval (correlations as hyperedges), and bioinformatics (biochemical interactions as hyperedges).

### Mathematical Tools

The hypergraph regularity method is a powerful tool in extremal graph theory that refers to the combined application of the hypergraph regularity lemma and the associated counting lemma, and is a generalization of the graph regularity method.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

### Key Concepts

## Replicator Dynamics

Based on the search results, here's an overview of replicator dynamics:

### Definition and Purpose

Replicator dynamics is a type of dynamical system used in evolutionary game theory to model how the frequency of strategies in a population changes over time.(no content)It is a simple model of strategy change commonly used in evolutionary game theory, where a strategy which does better than the average increases in frequency at the expense of strategies that do worse than the average.

### Key Characteristics

The replicator equation is a deterministic, monotone, non-linear, and non-innovative dynamic that captures the principle of natural selection.(no content)The replicator dynamics model heredity but not mutation, and assume asexual reproduction for the sake of simplicity.

### Growth Rate Principle

The growth rate of the proportion of organisms using a certain strategy is equal to the difference between the average payoff of that strategy and the average payoff of the population as a whole.

### Applications

Replicator dynamics have been widely applied in fields such as biology (to study evolution and population dynamics), economics (to analyze bounded rationality and strategy evolution), and machine learning (particularly in multi-agent systems and reinforcement learning).

### Mathematical Approaches

Since the replicator equation is non-linear, an exact solution is difficult to obtain (even in simple versions of the continuous form) so the equation is usually analyzed in terms of stability.

Web search results for query: "Evolutionary dynamics"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Eco-evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eco-evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Martin Nowak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Nowak"},{"title":"Evolutionary invasion analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_invasion_analysis"},{"title":"Red Queen hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Queen_hypothesis"},{"title":"Katsuhito Iwai - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhito_Iwai"},{"title":"Brigitte Pakendorf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brigitte_Pakendorf"},{"title":"Evolutionary arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_arms_race"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of evolutionary dynamics:

## Definition

Evolutionary dynamics is the study of the mathematical principles according to which biological organisms as well as cultural ideas evolve and evolved.(no content)This is mostly achieved through the mathematical discipline of population genetics, along with evolutionary game theory.

## Key Approaches

Several mathematical frameworks are used to study evolutionary dynamics:

- **Evolutionary Game Theory**: The common way to study the evolutionary dynamics in games is through replicator equations. These show the growth rate of the proportion of organisms using a certain strategy and that rate is equal to the difference between the average payoff of that strategy and the average payoff of the population as a whole.

- **Adaptive Dynamics**: Evolutionary invasion analysis, also known as adaptive dynamics, is a set of mathematical modeling techniques that use differential equations to study the long-term evolution of traits in asexually and sexually reproducing populations.

## Related Concepts

**Eco-evolutionary Dynamics**: Eco-evolutionary dynamics refers to the reciprocal effects that ecology and evolution have on each other.(no content)Increasing evidence shows that evolution can also operate on fine time scales simultaneously with ecological processes.

**Evolutionary Arms Races**: In evolutionary biology, an evolutionary arms race is an ongoing struggle between competing sets of co-evolving genes, phenotypic and behavioral traits that develop escalating adaptations and counter-adaptations against each other, resembling the geopolitical concept of an arms race.

These frameworks help researchers understand how populations change over time and how evolution shapes the natural world.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed a web search for "Social networks." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors. More specifically, a social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.

## Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim. Social scientists have used the concept of "social networks" since early in the 20th century to connote complex sets of relationships between members of social systems at all scales, from interpersonal to international.

## Modern Social Networking Services

A social networking service is a type of online social media platform which people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career content, interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites allow users to share ideas, digital photos and videos, posts, and to inform others about online or real-world activities and events with people within their social network.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory. It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

Web search results for query: "Public goods game"

Links: [{"title":"Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Collective action problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action_problem"},{"title":"Strong reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_reciprocity"},{"title":"CC–PP game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CC–PP_game"},{"title":"Talk:Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Public good - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_good"},{"title":"Samuelson condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuelson_condition"},{"title":"Lindahl tax - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindahl_tax"},{"title":"Dictator game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dictator_game"},{"title":"Public bad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_bad"}]

## Public Goods Game

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of the public goods game:

### Basic Definition

The public goods game is a standard of experimental economics.(no content)In the basic game, subjects secretly choose how many of their private tokens to put into a public pot.(no content)The common pool is then multiplied by some amount greater than one, then evenly redistributed to each participant, regardless of how much they contributed.

### Game Mechanics

Each individual is endowed with M tokens and must decide how many tokens to allocate to a public "pot" (public good).(no content)The payoff of each player is her "private consumption" (her endowment minus her contribution) plus her benefit from the public consumption.

### Key Findings

Interestingly, experimental results often contradict strict rational economic theory. In fact, the Nash equilibrium is rarely seen in experiments; people do tend to add something into the pot.(no content)The actual levels of contribution found varies widely (anywhere from 0% to 100% of initial endowment can be chipped in). Specifically, in a 2001 study, Fischbacher observed average contributions of 33.5%.

### Applications

Public goods games are valuable in understanding the role of incentives in an individual's behaviours. They arise from behavioural economics and have broad applications to societal challenges. Examples of applications include environmental policy, legal and justice issues and workplace and organisational structures.

Web search results for query: "Cooperation game theory"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Prisoner's dilemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoner's_dilemma"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Core (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Core_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Coordination game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordination_game"},{"title":"Cooperative game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game"},{"title":"Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Peace war game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_war_game"},{"title":"Urs Luterbacher - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urs_Luterbacher"}]

Here are the search results for **Cooperation Game Theory**:

## Overview

Cooperative game theory is a branch of game theory that deals with the study of games where players can form coalitions, cooperate with one another, and make binding agreements.(no content)The theory offers mathematical methods for analysing scenarios in which two or more players are required to make choices that will affect other players wellbeing.

## Key Characteristics

In game theory, a cooperative or coalitional game is a game with groups of players who form binding "coalitions" with external enforcement of cooperative behavior (e.g. through contract law). Some important features include:

- **Common Interests**: In cooperative games, players share a common interest in achieving a specific goal or outcome. The players must identify and agree on a common interest to establish the foundation and reasoning for cooperation.

- **Communication**: Cooperation requires communication and information exchange among the players. Players must share information about their preferences, resources, and constraints to identify opportunities for mutual gain.

- **Binding Agreements**: In cooperative games, agreements between players are binding and mandatory. Once the players have agreed to a particular course of action, they have an obligation to follow through.

## Contrast with Non-Cooperative Game Theory

Cooperative game theory models situations in which a binding agreement is possible. This differs fundamentally from non-cooperative games, where individual players act independently without enforcement mechanisms.

## Notable Concepts and Examples

Several important game theory scenarios relate to cooperation:

- **The Prisoner's Dilemma**: The prisoner's dilemma is a game theory thought experiment involving two rational agents, each of whom can either cooperate for mutual benefit or betray their partner ("defect") for individual gain.

- **Public Goods Game**: The game is used to study degree of altruism and cooperation between individuals. Public goods games are fundamental in experimental economics.

- **Evolution of Cooperation**: The book details a theory on the emergence of cooperation between individuals, drawing from game theory and evolutionary biology.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Evolutionary dynamics of higher-order interactions in social networks". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution`

The paper proposes a novel framework for studying cooperation in networked groups using higher-order interactions, making it a contribution paper.

**Identified Triples (6 total):**

1. **Evolutionary dynamics** (concept) - Uses
   - Core theoretical framework for studying strategy and cooperation evolution

2. **Social network** (concept) - Uses
   - The foundational structure for studying group cooperation

3. **Public goods game** (concept) - Uses
   - Game-theoretic model for analyzing group cooperation dynamics

4. **Hypergraph** (concept) - Proposes
   - Novel application to model higher-order group interactions

5. **Replicator equation** (method) - Uses
   - Mathematical framework linking network dynamics to well-mixed evolutionary dynamics

6. **Cooperative game theory** (concept) - Uses
   - Theoretical foundation for understanding group cooperation

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The triples_output.json file has been properly updated with all entities, their relationships to the paper, types, Wikipedia URLs, and relevance descriptions.
